Broader Environmental and Economic Impacts 
Considering the rapid expansion of the solar energy sector, understanding the full lifecycle impact of PV 
technologies‚Äîincluding end-of-life management‚Äîis critical. Future studies should also examine the broader 
environmental and economic impacts of implementing large-scale recycling operations, including potential reductions 
in greenhouse gas emissions, energy usage in recycling processes, and the overall carbon footprint of solar energy. 
 
This expanded discussion offers a comprehensive view of the potential and challenges of recycling PV cells, 
highlighting the necessity for continued innovation and policy support to harness these technologies for sustainable 
waste management. 
 
6. Conclusion  
This paper examined the potential for recycling critical materials from photovoltaic (PV) cells, particularly within the 
context of the United Arab Emirates (UAE). As the adoption of solar energy expands, the end-of-life waste from solar 
panels is projected to significantly increase, posing substantial waste management challenges. The study assesses the 
current production and material use in PV cells, anticipates the volume of waste generated, and discusses existing 
recycling efforts. It highlights the crucial need for advanced recycling technologies to efficiently reclaim valuable 
materials such as silicon, silver, and Indium from decommissioned solar panels. 
 
Based on the findings of this paper, it is recommended to develop Advanced Recycling Technologies within the UAE 
and to invest in research and development to enhance the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of recycling technologies. 
Focus on improving the recovery rates of critical materials like silicon, silver, and Indium, which are key components 
of PV cells not only from the solar panels waste generated from the UAE but also the solar panels waste generated 
from neighbor countries. 
It is recommended to implement regulatory frameworks and to establish and enforce regulations that mandate the 
recycling of materials from end-of-life PV cells. Such policies could include extended producer responsibility (EPR) 
requirements that hold manufacturers accountable for the disposal and recycling of solar panel waste. 
 
The implementation of policies shall be taking place with promoting industry collaboration. This takes place but 
encourage collaboration between governments, industry stakeholders, and research institutions to share knowledge, 
technologies, and best practices in recycling processes. This could accelerate the adoption of effective recycling 
technologies across the solar energy sector. 
 
In addition, the UAE as a leading partner in IRENA can lead the process of having global standards and cooperation. 
This shall be by working towards establishing international standards for the recycling of PV cells to ensure 
consistency and effectiveness in waste management practices globally. International cooperation could also facilitate 
the exchange of innovative recycling technologies and strategies. 
 
An important role to establish a system of recycling PV cells is the public. Therefore, it is suggested to have public 
awareness and education. The increase public awareness about the importance of recycling PV cells and the potential 
environmental benefits. Educational programs could help cultivate a culture of sustainability and encourage the proper 
disposal of solar panel waste. 
 
Finally, the economic incentives as providing financial incentives such as subsidies, tax breaks, or grants to companies 
that invest in solar panel recycling facilities or adopt green manufacturing processes. This could make the recycling 
process more appealing and economically viable. 
These recommendations aim to enhance the recycling of critical materials from PV cells, thereby supporting 
environmental sustainability and reducing the ecological footprint of solar energy production. 
 
As global energy demands transition towards renewable sources, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) is poised at the 
forefront of this shift with its significant investments in solar technology. However, this transition is accompanied by 
the burgeoning challenge of managing end-of-life photovoltaic (PV) cell waste, which is projected to see a dramatic 
increase over the coming decades. This paper has explored the current landscape of PV waste management and the 
feasibility of recycling critical materials within the UAE, reflecting broader global practices and technological 
advancements in this field.

The study underscores a critical need for robust recycling technologies that can effectively reclaim valuable materials 
such as silicon, silver, and Indium from decommissioned solar panels. While the current global efforts and emerging 
technologies show promise, particularly in the European Union and parts of Asia, there is a pressing need for localized 
strategies that cater to the specific environmental and industrial dynamics of the UAE. 
 
Conclusively, the sustainable management of solar panel waste not only addresses environmental concerns but also 
represents a significant economic opportunity for the recovery of precious materials. The UAE, with its strategic 
investments and policies, is well-positioned to lead by example in the innovation and implementation of effective 
waste management solutions. This will not only help mitigate the environmental impact of used PV cells but also 
bolster the economic viability of the renewable energy sector.

Abstract 
 Cyber Insurance (CI) is an important cyber risk management tool in industry and academia. Despite several 
commitments, its adoption rate is meagre. This research provides significant insights and analysis into the complex 
issues of i) identifying the key challenges in the cyber insurance (CI) market and ii) understanding how these 
influential challenges and their cause-effect relationships can inform policymakers to improve the CI ecosystem. An 
extensive literature review identified twenty-three challenges in the cyber insurance market. Industry experts in this 
field further validated these challenges, filtering them down to eleven major challenges for further analysis. The cause-
effect analysis of the challenges is determined using the fuzzy DEMATEL (FDEMATEL) approach. Finally, this 
study concludes that for a cyber insurance (CI) ecosystem to be successful, it is crucial to a) tackle the significant 
challenges posed by the cascading effects of correlated cyber risks and b) ensure the active participation of Chief 
Information Security Officers (CISOs) to grasp the CI value chain. 
Keywords 
Cyber security, Cyber Insurance, FDEMATEL, Correlated Cyber Risk. 
1. Introduction and Literature Review
The development of information technology reduces business costs and operation time but enhances information 
security risks at an unexpected level. In order to protect themselves from cyber risks, organizations are implementing 
various information security controls. However, complete mitigation of those cyber risks is not feasible. There was 
always an element of risk that cannot be mitigated. (Marotta et al. 2017.;Pal et al. 2014.;OECD. 2017) CI is designed 
to transfer those residual risks to a third party i.e., the insurer (Bohme 2005) . Despite several commitments, the CI 
adoption rate is abysmal (Meland et al. 2015;Eling, M., and Schnell,W. 2016.). Several studies have investigated the 
various barriers in the cyber insurance market, focusing on specific contexts such as small and medium businesses, 
geography-specific rules and regulations, and specific business scenarios (Meland et al. 2015;Woods, D., and Simpson 
2017). However, an exhaustive literature review revealed a lack of comprehensive studies on the major challenges in 
the cyber insurance market. To address this research gap, this study formulated the following research questions. RQ1:

5. Discussion 
Table 5 indicates that C1, C2, C4, C5, C6 and C7 are identified as cause alternatives, all characterized by a positive 
value when considering the difference (ri-ci) (Lin 2013). Moreover, these cause alternatives can be divided further into 
subgroups when looking at their prominence values (ri+ci), categorizing the challenges from a spectrum of low to 
high. C7 (The cascading effect of correlated cyber risk) is ranked high in prominence and scored as rank one. C4 and 
C5 also have significant prominence values (7.9816 and 8.148 consecutively) and also have causal influence power 
towards others' challenges.   Out of 11 interaction effects, six positive (ri-ci) values are identified as a causal group, 
and the remaining five have negative (ri+ci) values.  
 
On the other hand, out of 11 interaction effects, C3, C8, C9, C10 and  C11 fall under the effect group. The effect group 
is represented by the negative values of (ri-ci) (Lin 2013,Patil and Kant 2012). These are less influential in influencing 
others and are affected by cause group elements. C10 and C11 are getting maximum influenced by the causal group 
of elements. Hence, it is evident that the challenges of ‚ÄúHigh premium prices‚Äù and ‚ÄúDelays in the claim settlement 
process‚Äù are the worst consequences of the causal effect. These have a moderate prominence value (8.160 and 7.785, 
respectively) and are scored as rank 3 and rank 7, respectively. 
 
Considering the acceptable range of values (Above threshold values), the elements in the total relation matrix in Table 
6 are given three types of coloured shades, signifying different levels of interaction. It results in the following 
interaction effects: weak (red; values ranging from .3584 to .4096), moderate (yellow; values ranging from .4097 to 
.4608) and strong (green; values ranging from .4609 to .5119).

Abstract 
The present research is intended to investigate the concept of lean thinking in managing of supply chains with a 
specific focus on technical theoretical models and frameworks based on Industry 4.0 technologies. To create value, it 
is important in identification of steps required to value, mapping of the value stream and creation of rapid sequence 
steps for value creation as well as elimination of excessive material handling steps and reduce inefficiencies. This 
research adopts a methodological framework based on a hybrid model consisting of two proposed and existing 
conceptual models on the topic of research and performs a comparative analysis of the findings of the chosen models. 
According to the findings, the adoption of lean thinking practices in supply chains can be crucial in addressing existing 
constraints and challenges such as lack of strategic vision, lack of competent personnel and lack of understanding of 
the Industry 4.0 technologies, which pose significant challenge for the supply chains system. Essentially, the lean 
practices can be considered as standard indicators of weaknesses in supply chain operations.  
Keywords 
Industry 4.0, Simulation-Based Optimization, Lean Thinking, Supply Chains Sequence, Data Mining. 
1. Introduction
The application of lean thinking in supply chains typically entails the improvement of the involved processes based 
on the concepts of waste reduction, process simplification, and optimal value creation. The basic premise of lean 
thinking is the production of more value using fewer resources while providing the end-customer with the intended 
quality of the end-product (Vanichchinchai, 2019). The primary objective of lean supply chains is to produce an almost 
exact quantity of needed products, at the time needed, and where it is needed (Garcia-Buendia et al., 2021; Yu and 
Te, 2023). In the creation of value, lean supply chains determine the value system through the identification of steps 
required for value, mapping of the value stream, and creation of rapid sequence steps for value creation. In terms of 
waste reduction, the technique aims to stop defective products, eliminate excessive material handling steps, and reduce 
time wasted (Reyes et al., 2023; Cvetiƒá et al., 2023). In this regard, lean supply chains focus on improving value-
adding activities that can transform materials into end-products that the customer is willing to pay for while reducing

In terms of elements associated with the LSCM 4.0, the supply chain flows are based on a framework that consists of 
three interrelated sub-elements, including the network of the supply chain, which involves different stakeholders such 
as customers, producers, and suppliers; the supply chain business processes, which include techniques such as agile 
manufacturing and just-in-time (JIT); and, lastly, the supply chain management, which involves the relationship 
between the stakeholders and the applied management practices. According to the findings, the integration of the 
supply chain network, processes, and management with lean thinking practices based on Industry 4.0 technologies 
ensures the integration of the flow of information, materials, products, and finance with the different stakeholders, 
which ensures seamless supply chain operations. 
 
Secondly, in terms of risk management, the adoption of lean thinking practices in supply chains can be crucial in 
addressing existing constraints and challenges such as lack of strategic vision, lack of competent personnel, and lack 
of understanding of Industry 4.0 technologies, which pose significant challenges for the supply chain system. In 
essence, therefore, lean practices can be considered as standard indicators of weaknesses in supply chain operations 
and deliveries. 
 
Also, in relation to lean design, the findings show that the application of lean thinking principles provides the perfect 
opportunities for improvement of system flow through the elimination of non-added value, management of stakeholder 
relationships, and management of technological aspects of the supply chain. 
 
Lastly, the technological structure of the LSCM techniques provides useful information on the highly complex and 
automated manufacturing systems, services, and business processes that are applicable for ensuring optimal supply 
chain operations. 
 
5. Conclusion and Future Research Directions 
The primary objective of lean thinking principles in supply chains is to produce an almost exact quantity of needed 
products, at the time needed, and where it is needed. In the creation of value, lean supply chains determine the value 
system through the identification of steps required for value, mapping of the value stream, and creation of rapid 
sequence steps for value creation. The success of the application of these techniques is reliant on the sincerity of the 
relationship, which can further lead to the development of conflicts among the stakeholders of interest within the 
supply chains since most of the relationships are often adversarial rather than collaborative. There are theoretical 
models and frameworks that relate lean thinking principles with supply chains, and most of them focus on improving 
the relationship between the involved stakeholders to enhance value and eliminate waste. The present study provided 
an analytical review of existing literature on lean thinking in supply chain management with a specific focus on 
technical theoretical models and frameworks based on Industry 4.0 technologies and added to the existing literature 
on the research topic regarding the efficiency of supply chain management based on lean thinking principles. 
 
The research findings show that supply chain flows, technological structure, risk management, and lean manufacturing 
practices are crucial elements of lean thinking principles in supply chain management. These elements play an 
important role in various aspects of supply chains within an organization, including logistics, suppliers, collaborative 
management, strategic decision making, production, and marketing. Based on the results, it can be hypothesized that 
the integration of the supply chain network, processes, and management with lean thinking practices based on Industry

accuracy of the model to provide near-exact simulation-based forecasts for supply chain systems based on the value

Abstract 
This article seeks to establish how lean thinking has become a game-changer in enhancing operational excellence 
across various industries. Lean thinking, which originated in the Toyota production system, has evolved into a 
more general set of concepts for businesses. Among the lean manufacturing principles, value, value stream, flow, 
pull, and continuous improvement remain central to eliminating waste, increasing efficiency, and improving the 
value delivered to customers. This research focuses on both lean methodologies and lean tools such as Value 
Stream Mapping, 5S, Kaizen, Just-In-Time, Poka-Yoke, and Kanban. Practical examples and real-life cases 
demonstrate how lean thinking has provided substantial benefits in terms of waste elimination, product quality 
improvement, productivity rates, customer satisfaction, cost reduction, and employee motivation. However, the 
application of lean thinking is not without challenges, which may include resistance due to a lack of understanding, 
cultural barriers, and difficulties in measurement, among others. This analysis addresses these challenges and 
offers techniques for overcoming them and achieving successful lean transformation. The aim of this analysis is 
to distill insights from both the conceptual and managerial contexts of lean thinking that may be useful to 
organizations seeking operational excellence, cost reduction, and sustainable competitive advantage in today's 
challenging and highly competitive world. 
Keywords 
Lean Thinking, Operational Excellence, Waste Reduction, Continuous Improvement, Customer-Centricity. 
1. Introduction
In a modern world characterized by intense and ever-growing competition, business success is distinguished by 
one's ability to operate efficiently. Operational excellence is defined as the state of enduring high performance in 
organizations, catalyzed by regular optimization of key processes and consistent responsiveness to customer needs 
(Carvalho et al., 2020). It is not only specific to the task but also a concept that includes the optimality of creating 
as much value for the organization as possible and cutting costs from all angles within the organization. 
The core of operation management is lean thinking, a global movement and a set of practices that have changed 
the face of economic performance (Smith A, 2015). Born out of what is referred to as the Toyota Production 
System or lean manufacturing, lean thinking originated in the post-World War II Japanese automobile industry 
(Toyota Motor Corporation, 2023). Toyota's gripping story of consistent growth since its post-war beginnings, 
particularly founded on the organization's commitment to a unique management philosophy, namely, the 
elimination of waste and improvement of productive efficiency, drew the interest of businesses globally (Toyota

information and a reality check on the lean change process. 
 
6. Conclusion 
Lean thinking is a great example of how the various ideas and strategies of operative improvement and focusing 
on customer needs help to build up the environment for success. Its principles and methodologies are portable 
across organizations and have revolutionized industries by improving efficiency, effecting productivity and 
innovation, and minimizing cost. There are some obstacles in the implementation of such practices, but if 
leaders of organizations provide their subordinates with the proper training and encourage them to work on the 
formation of a new organizational culture, the problems under consideration will be solvable. 
 
The incorporation of lean as a digital concept along with sustainability shows that lean is a concept that remains 
relevant in the contemporary business environment. In an ever-competing and increasing transitional 
environment, lean thinking gives organizations an upper hand, thus directing them to a confirmed successful 
way of operating. Due to its focus on continuous change and the implementation of keen customer satisfaction, 
Lean is optimistic that it will remain a competency strength in management operations in the future.

Increased Efficiency: Lean Thinking helps to eradicate non-value creating activities and waste that enhance the 
operational effectiveness and efficiency of an organization. A fundamental lean principle known as Just-in-Time 
(JIT) production keeps inventory to a minimum while products and resources are acquired at the time they are 
required. It helps to cut the storage costs of excess stock and provide better acknowledgment of customers' 
requests. For instance, the MDPI journal research on production economics has confirmed that the application of 
JIT cut the production lead time and cost by over 70%. 
 
Enhanced Customer Satisfaction: Customer focus is created in Lean as it is oriented towards the understanding 
and creation of the value of the goods and services provided to customers. Because of a system that seeks to 
identify customer needs and preferences and a systematic approach that strives to have the right products ready at 
the right time, lean organizations possess thorough means that would enable them to meet and deliver more than 
the expectations of their customers. For example, the introduction of lean in a hospital led to decreased patient 
waiting time and enhanced communication, along with a positive score of patient satisfaction. 
 
Cost Reduction: The continuous outcomes in waste reduction, enhancements in quality, and increases in efficiency 
result in considerable cost savings. All types of waste, particularly those found in the lean system, including stocks 
on hand, wasteful processes, and flawed products, are great costs to the firm (Milewski, 2022). When quality is 
enhanced, it leads to less demand for inspections and rework, which are expensive exercises; therefore, it reduces 
costs. Efficiency increases result in resources being used optimally, leading to lower costs. 
 
Employee Engagement: Lean Thinking also covers aspects of employee involvement, improvement, and 
knowledge sharing. This is well exemplified in the Kaizen business management system, where everyone in the 
business organization is encouraged to provide and participate in improvement initiatives. It not only promotes 
the spirit of the employees' involvement and responsibility in their work but also utilizes their experience and 
ideas, which in turn creates creativity and a high morale among them. A survey of a service organization's 
experience revealed that lean methods boosted employee contentment and organizational performance by over 
50% (Schwantz et al., 2023). Those businesses that adopt lean thinking as their management values can be 
considered to be on the right track towards gaining a competitive advantage in a world economy that is becoming 
progressively more challenging. 
 
5. Implementation Challenges  
It is equally important to note that lean thinking does not come without its challenges. One of the challenges for 
change management is resistance to change, which is usually caused by several factors, some of which are fear of 
the unknown or threats from change processes to already existing practices (Primeast, 2020). This can be 
counteracted through intervention that comprises achieving extensive leadership, communication, and 
accomplishment of change through engaging the employees. Likewise, one should stress the advantages of lean 
and explain doubts that may arise while implementing lean; this generates ownership and increases interest in the 
transformation process. 
 
The other major issue is the general misunderstanding of Lean concepts and practices. The issues and 
recommendations of Lean go beyond the mere use of operational tools and practices and are a complete system 
of management thought. To facilitate the use of lean thinking at the workplace, extensive training and education 
procedures are necessary in order to provide employees with the necessary knowledge and skills. It covers the 
philosophy with regards to particular approaches such as VSM, 5S, the Kaizen methodology, and others, while 
developing a conceptual approach to continuous improvement and elimination of waste. 
 
There are also institutional factors that can hinder lean adoption; these are cultural issues (Zimmermann and 
Bollbach, 2015). This is because certain organizational cultures may not easily embrace the changes that Lean 
brings with it, including the utilization of employees and their collaboration, as well as the constant striving for 
perfection. Of these cultural barriers, it is crucial to address leadership commitment, cultural surveys, and change 
strategies to integrate the organization's culture with Lean. This may include such practices as reducing certain 
hierarchical barriers to communication, rewarding risk-taking, and acknowledging the part played by workers in 
the process of change. 
 
Lastly, the assessment and monitoring of the lean principles' effectiveness are also necessary for implementation. 
The development of relevant and specific Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that are in line with Lean's goals 
allows companies to assess the alterations, reinforce good working practices, and recognize achievements. The 
KPIs can be defined as key performance indicators that encompass lead time reduction, inventory turnover, the 
rate of defects, and the customers' satisfaction ratings (Lara et al., 2023). These are actualizations that should form

Abstract 
 Lathe machines are a technological advancement involved in cutting and shaping materials and are widely used 
across several industries. However, many injuries and fatalities arise due to the improper handling of the machine 
and its malfunction. A range of safety approaches have been developed to reduce incidents from training to P.P.E. 
Nevertheless, incidents still occur due to the unpredictability of the machine's function and human error. In our 
approach to taking on this issue, we proposed a system that identifies potential accidents through computer vision 
and records potential risks in real time with the help of a deep learning model. Based on previous studies, our 
proposed method shows great potential in the advancement of health and safety measures to reduce on-site damage 
to equipment and personnel. 
 Keywords 
Lathe machine, accidents, A.I., safety, cameras. 
1. Introduction
A lathe machine, a cornerstone in the world of manufacturing and engineering, is designed for shaping and 
machining various materials, including metal, wood, and plastic. By rotating the workpiece on its axis against cutting 
tools, lathes allow for precise and intricate shaping, making them indispensable in the production of symmetrical 
objects and parts. Despite their utility, operating these machines comes with inherent risks. Accidents involving 
lathes, often resulting from unsafe working conditions or equipment malfunctions, can lead to severe injuries, 
fatalities, and substantial material losses (Bureau of Labor Statistics,2020). 
Recent statistics highlight the gravity of this issue: Also, in 2020, machinery and equipment-related fatalities 
constituted 15% of total fatalities in the United States (U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2020). Analyzing the data 
regarding accidents and diseases in working industries, it is worth mentioning that the primary causes were machines, 
at least in terms of mining significance (U.S. Mining Industry Report, 2010). Perhaps one of the most discussed 
pieces of equipment in this regard is the lathe. For example, there have been a lot of reports on how lathe accidents 
happen frequently, which calls for a strong and efficient organization to avoid them. This report is concerned with 
the assessment of the key operational variables for lathe machines, identification of trends in the control systems, 
and evaluation of the measures that can be taken to minimize the risks of accidents in order to improve the safety 
and performance of these machines. The full adoption of Artificial Intelligence solutions in safety measures could 
have the potential of changing safety measures through real-time surveillance and the use of Artificial intelligence 
to predict accidents before they happen (Weerasinghe et al., 2012).

4.3 Deep Learning Model 
  Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) is a deep learning algorithm that processes patterns from visual content and 
is especially useful in computer vision applications (Mandal, 2023). To utilize this model, important features will first 
be extracted from the database created using image capturing, including posture, joint angles, motion patterns, speed 
of movements, distance from potential hazards, lathe machine parts, and the presence of safety hazards. Such features 
will be annotated with labels to indicate whether the practices are normal or deviated and to categorize worker's 
performance. The labeled data will be input into the CNN model land and will be randomly divided into training and 
testing sets. To detect movement and proximity (operator and machine) for hazard evaluation, the coordinates of the 
objects obtained from the model will be used. The deep learning model will be integrated into the monitoring system 
using a Software Development Kit (SDK) interface (Liu et al. 2019), and the surveillance will then be assessed for 
abnormalities in real-time. 
 
4.4 Alert Mechanism 
 Severity levels of abnormal behaviors will be identified based on the categorization of the worker's performance, 
and warning alerts will be generated depending on the level of the risk conditions (Table 1). The abnormal behavior 
may be less severe, in which case the alert can be displayed on a dashboard or a monitor within the operator's vision 
as flash warnings and as sound alerts to enhance the attraction of the operator. In the case of severe danger, the 
machine may have an emergency shutdown mechanism whereby the machine's operation will be halted to prevent 
the occurrence of an accident.

Conclusion 
Due to the high prevalence of injuries (nonfatal and fatal) whilst operating on lathe machines, it is necessary to take 
proactive safety measures to prevent such incidents. Our proposed method involves predicting and preventing injuries 
by utilizing deep learning and computer vision to identify unsafe acts, record the act in real-time, and generate an alert 
to notify the worker of a potential hazard. Moreover, this information can be used for training and educational 
purposes, furthering the safety of the workers involved. Based on the high accuracy of the model demonstrated by 
Luoetal., our model shows great potential to be applied by management-site; however, a multidisciplinary team is 
required to fully implement the strategy while paying more attention to the details of the model's logarithm.

Abstract 
Effective Improvement the loan portfolio is crucial for banks as it directly influences their profitability and overall 
performance. Effective Improvement allows banks to achieve greater diversification, enhance asset quality, and 
improve liquidity management. Profitability and liquidity risk management of this portfolio are influenced by 
several factors, with the budget allocated to each product being one of the most significant. This budget directly 
impacts profitability and customer satisfaction. The product budget refers to the maximum loan amount that the 
bank offers to customers for each product. In this research, we aim to create an appropriate portfolio of bank loan 
products by analyzing the behavior of loan applicants and determining the budget ceiling for each product. Our 
objective is to meet the diverse needs of our customers, including the amount and variety of loans, while 
maximizing profitability. To achieve this goal, we employ a fourth-step approach. First, we analyze customer 
behavior and create a simulation model to determine the budget ceiling increase for each product. Second, due to the 
large number of scenarios, we use the design of experiments approach to select and evaluate a subset of scenarios 
using the simulation model. Subsequently, we employ a neural network approach to assess the remaining scenarios. 
Finally, we develop a mathematical model for the optimal allocation of funds to different products, resulting in the 
formation of the optimal product portfolio. The results of the proposed approach, compared to the bank's 
performance last year, demonstrate average improvements of 9.2% in profitability and 8.7% in customer 
satisfaction, underscoring the effectiveness of our method. 
Keywords 
Product Portfolio, loans, Discrete-Event Simulation, Artificial Neural Network, Mathematical Modeling, Retail 
Banking.

Abstract 
The purpose of this study is to investigate the use of lean tools in the improvement of warehouses in terms of reducing 
costs and waste in a warehouse. After the determination of waste, specific lean tools were used to reduce waste and 
improve the performance of the warehouse. To evaluate the warehouse efficiency, value stream mapping, 
benchmarking, and activity profiling were used. The combination of these three tools facilitates the identification of 
waste in the warehouse that would have been challenging to identify using only one tool. As a solution to reduce lead 
time and non-value-added activities in the warehouse, various lean tools including 5S and visual management were 
implemented. The main critical issue in applying lean is to sustain the work and to sustain the idea of continuous 
improvement, hence employees‚Äô training was key in improvement. A future state map was conducted after applying 
lean tools, it was concluded that the lead time has decreased by 25%, and non-value-added activities time was reduced 
by 33% in various operations such as loading, receiving, storage, inspection, and order picking. 
Keywords 
Lean Tools, Warehouse, Improvement, 5S, Visual Management 
1. Introduction
In their book, ‚ÄòLean Thinking‚Äô, Womack et al. (1996) introduced the lean production philosophy to the Western world. 
According to them, lean thinking entails the following: defining value, aligning value-added tasks in the optimal 
sequence, and performing these activities uninterrupted. To achieve this, it is very important to follow the main 
principles of lean thinking introduced by Womack et al.: 
‚Ä¢
Specify value from the customer‚Äôs point of view.
‚Ä¢
Map all the product‚Äôs value streams.
‚Ä¢
Design flow within the organization.
‚Ä¢
Manufacture based on the customer‚Äôs need (establish pull).
‚Ä¢
Seek perfection.
Warehouses play a significant part in the logistics system of any company. Companies use warehouses as a source of 
time and space to deliver raw resources, work-in-progress, and final outputs. It consists of multiple processes including 
receiving, storing, and shipping of the products or items. The activities of a warehouse include the receipt and

Taking the financial constraints into account, the optimal solution for implementing lean tools in the warehouse was 
to use low-cost resources such as board, colored papers, cleaning tools, and pins. Another limitation to apply lean 
concepts in the warehouse is availability of different resources such as time and workers. It was difficult to apply lean 
tools in the whole warehouse in the project duration. Moreover, it was difficult to apply all steps of 5S in all the 
locations, as it required a larger number of workers and more material handling equipment. Humans and other errors 
are responsible for various errors in the current and future construction of value stream mapping. The duration of each 
process was recorded multiple times for more accuracy.  
 
6. Conclusions 
In this work, lean manufacturing tools were used for improvement in a warehouse of a large retail company specialized 
in electronics and accessories. VSM, activity profiling, and benchmarking were utilized throughout the evaluation 
procedure. The current state of value stream mapping gives a snapshot of the situation in the warehouse with all the 
required processes. It identifies where materials and items are in storage, where overproduction occurs, and how many 
personnel are engaged in various activities. However, The VSM will not provide a massive data set detailing, for 
example, how consumers order from warehouses or whether products are frequently requested together. Activity 
Profiling accomplishes this, which was a crucial consideration when selecting this concept for this study. Both cannot 
define the warehouse's performance, so benchmarking was used with various KPIs to measure the warehouse's 
performance based on standards as determined by the gap analysis. The model used in this research combines TPS, 
kaizen, HRM, and quality management. This model has features that make it highly pertinent to warehouse systems; 
it is extensive in design, simple to implement in a variety of warehouse types, and useful in the warehouse evaluation 
process. The aim is to use a model to apply lean in warehouse and use this model as a study resource in workshops 
conducted to explain the lean concepts to workers. The proposed implemented changes could reduce lead time by 
25%, reduce Non-value added time by 33%, and reducing WIP by 30%.

GPT-Powered Case-based Domain Knowledge Modeling 
and Reasoning for Cognitive Intelligent Manufacturing 
Defect Mitigation 
Shu Wang, Chenxi Tao, Mulang Song, Yiyun (Cindy) Fei, Liuyang Shan and Roger J. Jiao 
School of Mechanical Engineering 
 Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA 
shu.wang@gatech.edu 
Abstract 
Manufacturing defect mitigation focuses on identifying the causes of defects and reducing their occurrence by 
adjusting process configurations. This requires the development of a smart decision-making system that can assist in 
self-configuration and self-optimization of a production line. To achieve this, this paper proposes a case-based domain 
knowledge modeling and reasoning approach for cognitive intelligent defect mitigation using knowledge graphs and 
generative artificial intelligence (GenAI). Unlike conventional case-based reasoning, the proposed approach employes 
knowledge graph database for knowledge modeling and case representation, enhancing the efficiency of case retrieval. 
Additionally, the large-language model (LLM) is employed to assist in knowledge acquisition and knowledge 
reasoning for case adaptation. An example of defect mitigation in an assembly line with in-process inspection is 
presented to validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach. 
Keywords 
Defect mitigation, Cognitive intelligence, Case-based reasoning, Large-language model, Knowledge Graph 
1. Introduction
Since the advent of Industry 4.0, manufacturing industries have been continuously integrating cutting-edge 
technologies into various applications, creating a more dynamic and complex manufacturing environment. New 
characteristics have emerged within the manufacturing system, including high-precision manufacturing, high-mix 
low-volume manufacturing, self-configuration, self-optimization, and so on. During production, manufacturing 
inspection plays an important role in ensuring product quality by identifying defective parts. Additionally, inspection 
aids in process control by mitigating defect generation through a manufacturing-inspection-mitigation control loop. 
This self-configuration process, known as defect mitigation, involves mitigation planning to adjust process 
configurations which produce defect parts by inferencing inspection results (Borish et al., 2019).  
1.1 Manufacturing Defect Mitigation 
In the manufacturing industry, defect mitigation encompasses the methodologies and tactics aimed at minimizing, 
controlling, and eradicating defects in products, systems, and processes. This approach is pivotal in enhancing the 
efficiency and sustainability of manufacturing operations (Psarommatis et al., 2021). Advanced data-driven 
technologies are instrumental in this context, facilitating real-time monitoring and predictive maintenance, which are 
essential for effective defect mitigation. The implementation of robust data management systems is crucial as it ensures 
the accuracy and usability of data for defect detection and classification (Thung et al., 2012). Research underscores 
the importance of a strong data management system and effective information management in achieving successful 
defect mitigation (Woo & O‚ÄôConnor, 2021).

8. Concluding Remarks 
This paper has presented a novel approach to manufacturing defect mitigation through cognitive intelligent case-based 
reasoning, utilizing generative AI and knowledge graphs. The proposed approach is validated with a case of ultrasonic 
welding defect mitigation for its feasibility and effectiveness.  
 
There are several contributions of this paper. Firstly, by leveraging LLMs for knowledge acquisition and inference, 
the proposed system offers a robust solution for defect detection and mitigation in dynamic and complex 
manufacturing environments. Secondly, the integration of knowledge graphs also enhances the efficiency of 
knowledge modeling, facilitating case representation and retrieval. Thirdly, case adaptation is enhanced through a 
RAG application, increasing the flexibility of case-based reasoning. In conclusion, the proposed cognitive intelligent 
case-based reasoning approach not only works in the field of manufacturing defect mitigation but can be applied to 
other applications to improve reasoning quality and efficiency.

GAI-based Intelligent Cognitive Assistant for 
Urban Rideshare Safety Recommendation Services 
Chenxi Tao, Roosan Liyons, Roger J. Jiao and Seung-Kyum Choi 
School of Mechanical Engineering 
Georgia Institute of Technology 
Atlanta, GA, USA  
ctao40@gatech.edu 
Abstract 
Urban rideshares have become a cornerstone of urban transportation, offering unparalleled convenience and presenting 
a significant market opportunity. However, safety concerns are escalating as their usage proliferates. By harnessing 
advancements in computer vision and mobile technologies, alongside the widespread adoption of shared vehicles, 
urban rideshare systems can now deliver real-time road information and safety advisories. A critical gap remains in 
predictive capabilities and the translation of image data into human-understandable language or actionable safety 
recommendations. This paper investigates the potential of creating a real-time generative AI-based intelligent 
cognitive assistant for updating road information, specifically designed for urban rideshare safety recommendation 
services. Utilizing computer vision to collect road data during rides, the platform employs a generative AI database to 
comprehensively store and analyze this information. Users receive immediate safety updates through intuitive 
interfaces using a retrieval-augmented generation system. To demonstrate the ICA‚Äôs viability, a test case of shared e-
scooters is studied, showcasing the system's effectiveness and potential impact on urban scooter rideshare safety. This 
test case highlights how the GAI-based ICA can enhance the safety and reliability of urban rideshare services by 
providing timely and accurate safety information and recommendations. 
Keywords 
Generative Artificial Intelligence, Large Language Models, Retrieval-Augmented Generation, Knowledge Graphs, 
Urban Rideshare Safety 
1. Introduction
The rideshare system is widely used in urban environments, providing convenience for daily public life and 
representing a significant market opportunity. Service providers such as Citi Bike, Lime, and Bird quickly achieved a 
strong service-market fit, reaching billion-dollar valuations shortly after their inception (Ma et al. 2021). Ensuring the 
safety of riders is paramount for both the users and the rideshare companies. Much research has focused on this area, 
examining data analysis aspects (Zakhem and Colin 2024) and policy regulation analysis (Riggs et al. 2021). However, 
practical methods for real-life applications to monitor road conditions and provide safety suggestions are still limited. 
With recent advancements in computer vision technology, numerous methods have been developed to monitor road 
conditions. For instance, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) can be trained on pavement images to create deep 
learning models that provide detailed information on road conditions (Zhang et al. 2016). Mobile device cameras, 
being highly accessible and convenient, can be combined with computer vision technologies to become powerful and 
easy-to-use tools for daily applications. Modern computer vision technology has leveraged data from simple sensors 
in cell phones, employing methods such as K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and Support Vector Machines (SVMs) for 
model training (Ashqar et al. 2020). Therefore, with the help of computer vision technologies and modern mobile 
device sensors, road safety conditions and traffic information can be effectively gathered and analyzed. However,

6. Rideshare Safety Recommendation Chatbot Interface 
After setting up the database and RAG system, a final chatbot interface is essential for providing user feedback. The 
chatbot retrieves safety information from the database and offers safety suggestions based on the calculated safety 
score. Once a real-time image is provided and the safety score is calculated, the chatbot automatically generates and 
displays the safety suggestions to the user. This interface ensures users receive timely and relevant safety information 
in an easily accessible manner. Figure 9 shows an example of the user interface. 
 
7. Conclusions 
This paper proposes the GenICA as a new concept designed to generate road safety information and test its feasibility. 
The GenICA, embedded with a knowledge graph database and generative algorithms for information retrieval, has 
been examined and compared to traditional online recommendation systems. The GenICA provides users with 
enhanced situational awareness and serves as a reference for self-generation. It offers deeper insights into data features 
for designers monitoring the system, highlighting the generative capabilities of the model. The GenICA allows for the 
generative application of industrial knowledge, showcasing its potential to improve road safety and provide valuable 
information to both users and designers. 
 
However, there are limitations to this approach. One significant issue is hallucination, where large language models 
generate incorrect or misleading answers. This can result in significantly wrong advice being provided during riding, 
even when performing the same function or building the same model. To mitigate this, more specific knowledge 
should be generalized and standardized to minimize discrepancies. Additionally, real-life environmental conditions 
are crucial to consider, as real traffic is more complex and can dramatically affect the analysis process, potentially 
causing instability. Therefore, future work should focus on training the model with more specific knowledge and 
refining the learning process to enhance its reliability and accuracy.

Ryan Tan, Harry Yang and Sean Jiao

Liuyang Shan, Chenxi Tao and Roger J. Jiao 
School of Mechanical Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332, USA

Abstract 
This paper explores the application of a robotic arm powered by artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning to 
enhance the precision and efficiency of object manipulation tasks. Leveraging OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4o image recognition 
model along with OpenCV, we implement smart computer vision techniques to accurately recognize, locate, and 
manipulate targeted objects. By automating control and minimizing human intervention, our approach has the potential 
for improving traditional kinematics-based methods. The integration of AI enables robots to learn from vision data, 
adapt to various scenarios, and improve over time. Our findings demonstrate the feasibility of utilizing AI and deep 
learning to achieve high accuracy and efficiency in robot manipulation, with profound implications for manufacturing 
automation and beyond. 
Keywords 
Smart manufacturing, Robot manipulation, Large-language model, GPT vision, Machine learning 
1. Introduction
Robot manipulation refers to the ability of a robot to interact with objects in its environment, typically through the use 
of a robotic arm or end-effector (gripper, tool, etc.). This involves a range of tasks such as grasping, moving, placing, 
and assembling objects. Robot manipulation is a crucial aspect of robotics because it enables robots to perform 
complex tasks that require precision, dexterity, and adaptability. Robot manipulation is a cornerstone of manufacturing 
automation, enabling the development of sophisticated and efficient automated systems that can perform a wide range 
of tasks with high precision and reliability (Anderson and Kurez, 2024). 
With this problem in mind, we explore the application of a robotic arm powered by artificial intelligence (AI) and 
deep learning to recognize, locate, and manipulate targeted objects. The release of OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4 model has 
significantly advanced computer vision capabilities, allowing for seamless access through simple prompts. Its 
enhanced contextual and language understanding surpasses the limitations and rigidity of previous vision models. This 
benefit enables the GPT model to be utilized in a variety of scenarios, reducing the need for programs to be specifically 
tailored to a single use case (Liu et al., 2021). 
This research is motivated by the need to improve efficiency and precision in robot manipulation. Manual calibration 
of robot control not only consumes valuable time but also introduces the possibility of human error. By automating 
these tasks, we aim to minimize errors, increase throughput, and equip robot manipulation with vision-based 
intelligence. The application of Large Language Models (LLMs) and deep learning neural networks in robot 
manipulation presents many advantages over traditional kinematics-based methods (Liu et al., 2024). AI enables 
robots to learn from vision data, adapt to new use cases, and improve their performance over time as more valid data 
is used for self-training throughout their lifespan. Deep learning, a subset of AI, allows for the development of

7. Concluding Remarks 
By harnessing OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4o model in conjunction with computer vision capabilities like OpenCV, this study 
illustrates great potential in object recognition, localization, and manipulation within robotic arm systems. The GPT-
powered smart robot control approach not only automates manual calibration processes but also reduces errors, 
enhances throughput, and enhances adaptability to diverse environments. By integrating AI and deep learning, robots 
can autonomously learn from visual data, continually improving their performance over time. This represents a 
promising shift towards more intelligent and efficient automated manufacturing. These findings highlight the 
transformative potential of AI in robotics, offering extensive applications across various industrial sectors beyond 
traditional kinematics-based methods.

The Sustainability Triangle for Urban Forest Development in 
the Capital City of the Indonesian Archipelago 
Yenita, Roesdiman Soegiarso, Oei Fuk Jin 
Faculty of Engineering 
Universitas Tarumanagara 
Letjen S. Parman No. 1, West Jakarta, Indonesia 
yenita@fe.untar.ac.id 
Abstract 
This research explores the application of the Sustainability Triangle in the development of forest city to address 
critical environmental challenges facing modern urban areas, with a special focus on the development of forest city 
in Indonesia's new capital city (IKN). Forest cities integrate extensive vegetation into the urban environment, 
offering an effective ecological solution while providing significant economic and social benefits. By improving air 
quality through the absorption of carbon dioxide and other pollutants, urban forests contribute to a healthier urban 
atmosphere. Additionally, urban vegetation helps reduce the urban heat island effect by lowering surface 
temperatures and reducing energy requirements for cooling. Urban forests also function as habitats for various flora 
and fauna, increasing biodiversity and ecological balance. Analysis carried out on existing urban forest projects at 
IKN, highlights the important role of commitment and collaboration between government, the private sector, local 
communities, and research institutions in the success of these initiatives. Policy recommendations, such as 
increasing community participation, adopting environmentally friendly technologies, diversifying plant species, and 
developing supportive policies, aim to strengthen and optimize the implementation of urban forests. This research 
makes a significant contribution to the academic literature and practice of sustainable urban development, 
demonstrating that the forest city concept is an effective and comprehensive approach to addressing urban 
environmental challenges. It is hoped that the sustainable development and implementation of this concept can 
create future cities that are more environmentally friendly, economically competitive, and socially prosperous. 
Keywords 
Sustainability Triangle, Urban Forest, Development, Construction, Indonesia. 
1. Introduction
Sustainability has become an important issue in global development in the economic, environmental, and social 
sectors. Sustainability challenges are increasingly prominent in the context of urban development, requiring 
strategic planning and implementation to balance economic growth, environmental conservation, and social welfare 
(Kleine & von Hauff, 2009). Amid these dynamics, the ambitious project for Indonesia's new capital or Indonesian 
National Capital (IKN) has emerged as the focus of attention. The Indonesian government has ambitious plans to 
develop a new capital city (IKN) with a forest city concept, which aims to mitigate environmental damage, 
especially in forest areas. The concept of forest cities has received much attention in discussions around 
urbanization and sustainability. Forest cities offer innovative solutions to various environmental problems facing 
modern cities, such as air pollution, urban heat island effect, and loss of biodiversity (Ibrahim et al., 2023). Over the 
past few decades, extensive research has been conducted to explore the potential of urban forests in creating 
healthier and more sustainable urban environments. This concept is not just a temporary trend but is an integral part 
of modern urban planning strategies that integrate ecological principles with urban development (Gabrys, 2022). 
Rapid urbanization has negative impacts on the environment, such as air pollution, noise, urban heat islands, and

Increasing research and development is another important improvement. Increased investment in research and 
development related to urban forests, including studies of ecological, social, and economic benefits, could enrich 
knowledge and best practices. Collaborating with universities and research institutions is essential to obtain new 
data and insights that can be used to improve urban forest design and implementation, adapt to changing 
conditions, and improve forest management strategies. 
 
Public education and awareness campaigns are also important. Launching an educational campaign to increase 
public awareness about the importance and benefits of urban forests can be done through social media, seminars 
and educational programs in schools. These campaigns increase public understanding and support for urban forest 
development and conservation efforts, building a culture of environmental stewardship and sustainable living. 
 
Finally, fostering multisectoral collaboration is the key to successful urban forest management. Building 
collaboration between government, private sector, NGO‚Äôs and local communities in urban forest planning and 
management ensures that all stakeholders are actively involved. This multisectoral approach increases the 
effectiveness and sustainability of urban forestry programs through synergy between various stakeholders, 
leveraging diverse expertise and resources to achieve better results. 
 
By implementing these proposed improvements, the development of forest cities can be optimized more effectively 
to achieve sustainability goals, improve the quality of life of residents, and preserve the environment. This strategic 
action will contribute to creating a greener, healthier and more resilient urban environment. 
 
6. Conclusion 
This research highlights the importance of applying the forest city concept in addressing various environmental 
problems facing modern cities, including air pollution, urban heat island impact, and loss of biodiversity. Through 
the integration of vegetation into the urban environment, forest cities not only offer an effective ecological solution 
but also provide significant economic and social benefits. Urban forests can significantly reduce air pollution 
through the ability of trees and plants to absorb carbon dioxide and other pollutants while releasing oxygen. In 
addition, vegetation in urban forests can lower urban surface temperatures, reduce the heat island impact, and 
reduce energy requirements for cooling. Urban forests also provide natural habitats for various species of flora and 
fauna, increasing biodiversity and maintaining ecosystem balance. The presence of urban forests can increase 
property values, attract tourists, and create new economic opportunities in the tourism and environmental education 
sectors, as well as reduce public health costs through improving air quality. Additionally, urban forests offer green 
spaces that encourage physical activity, recreation, and social interaction, which collectively improve the quality of 
life for their residents. 
 
This research also identifies the importance of balancing the three main pillars of sustainability, namely 
environmental, economic, and social, which can be achieved through the application of the sustainability triangle 
theory in the development of forest cities. Analysis of existing urban forestry projects shows that the success of 
these initiatives relies heavily on the commitment and collaboration of various parties, including government, the 
private sector, local communities, and research institutions. The policy recommendations suggested in this research, 
such as increasing community participation, adopting green technology, diversifying plant species, and developing 
supporting policies, aim to strengthen and optimize the implementation of urban forests in the future. With a strong 
framework and active participation from various stakeholders, forest cities can be a real and sustainable solution for 
creating greener, healthier, and more prosperous cities. 
 
This research is expected to make a significant contribution to the academic literature and practice of sustainable 
urban development, providing evidence that the forest city concept is an effective and comprehensive approach to 
addressing urban environmental challenges. By continuing to develop and apply this concept, it is hoped that future 
cities will be more environmentally friendly, economically competitive, and prosperous for their residents.

Maria Henriqueta Almeida 
Researcher at UNIDEMI Research and Development Unit for Mechanical and Industrial

NOVA School of Science and Technology 
Caparica, Portugal 
mh.sousa@alumni.fct.unl.pt 
Abstract 
The people dimension in the service industry is a critical asset, where companies have the pressure to retain talent and 
continuously deliver value to their customers. Sharing knowledge among employees is crucial to sustain quality 
services and incorporate the voice of the customer in their activities. As Lean Service (LS) is the application of Lean 
principles to service, this research aims to present how LS can develop and enhance a team learning process. Hence, 
using a mixed methods approach, combining qualitative and quantitative data, and through case study research, two 
years of investigation were performed. Based on the set up of different and innovative action learning activities, which 
enrolled a universe of 73 workers, it was possible to perform 27 innovative training sessions, which represented an 
amount of 114 training hours to 170 participants, where an average of 89% of success was obtained. Additionally, an 
organised and standard on-job training process was set up with 6 communities of practice (CP), and over one year, 80 
on-job training hours were delivered by subject matter experts. Each CP is working on a daily basis as a Lean cell, 
producing and sharing knowledge within the organisation, and addressing problem-solving. The study highlights the 
potential of Lean Service in developing and enhancing team learning and provides actionable insights for effective 
interventions in people‚Äôs dimension. 
Keywords 
Learning, Team Learning, Lean, Lean Service, Service Industry. 
1. Introduction
As Lean can be applied to whichever organisation (Womack and Jones 2003), it is possible to move production 
principles to services (Levitt, 1972), and literature demonstrates the applicability of Lean to the service industry 
(Osborne et al. 2013; Radnor et al. 2013; dos Reis and Vieira, 2015; Ferreira et al. 2018). Hence, Lean Service is the 
application of Lean principles to services (Ahlstrom 2004). 
In Bowen and Youngdahl‚Äôs (1998) research, the first Lean study in service industries, the relevance of people in Lean 
adoption was pointed out, as well as the risks of a Lean implementation without considering this critical success factor. 
Consequently, the relationship between Lean and people is identified in the literature review (Ciano‚Äôs et al. 2019).      
As services are delivered by people-to-people (Gupta et al. 2016), the service industry is highly dependent on human 
resources, thus, this research focuses on the contextual as well as on the technological aspects of Lean Service in 
peoples‚Äô domain, particularly in the learning domain. Hence, the purpose is to study how Lean, based on action 
learning activities, can develop and enhance a team learning process within a service organisation. 
Tan et al. (2023) presented different field-training interventions from the literature to demonstrate its positive effects 
on employees, particularly on divergent thinking and problem-solving behaviour. These authors cited several studies

Regarding the average dropout rate over this period, from the participants who filled in the form and not attending the 
sessions, the rate was 3.5% and the attendance average of participants was 21 per session. As each session had an 
evaluation form, the average achieved in all sessions was 89%. From the trainers‚Äô point of view, as they were all 
internal workers (managers and subject matter experts) it was possible to invite and involve a total of 16 trainers along 
the 27 sessions, which were supported by the project team.  
On average and per each training session, 3 documents were produced or reviewed representing more than 80 training 
materials produced/reviewed over these two years of investigation. This material will be reutilized for next training 
editions and future customer training.  
Additionally, and in each community of practice (CP) per knowledge subject, the subject matter experts (SME) are 
providing on-job-training to members based on a defined plan. On average, 80 planned hours of on-job-training were 
performed over one year, between SME and contact persons, plus the hours of unstructured communication spent 
daily through the Microsoft Teams chats when it was required to work in problem-solving. Furthermore, analysing 
the last figures of customer requests answered by each worker, it was possible to verify the increase of number of 
employees who are now replying and helping others in problem-solving.  
As a Lean journey can transform workers into thinkers, improving their technical competences as well as the soft 
skills, particularly team building, polyvalence, decision-making, assumptions of responsibility, self-learning and self-
adaptation (Alves, Dinis-Carvalho and Sousa 2012), during this team learning process with Lean Service, 5 team 
building sessions were held to invest in team working and networking.  
In the same way, as Emiliani (1998) raised the importance of empowering Lean behaviours such as self-awareness, 
humility, compassion, calmness, reflection, honesty, consistency, and generosity (Almeida-Sousa 2021), these 
behaviours were also addressed during the process. However, in doing so, during the on-job training both managers 
and co-workers realised the real and negative impacts of the pandemic situation and its consequences in the workers‚Äô 
personal lives, thus, in their mental health. 
Additionally, the changes introduced by the hybrid work and the new ways of working, particularly more 
communication channels and new procedures, had also effects on the workers‚Äô mental health. Therefore, to help its 
work force, in 2023 X set up a psychologist line plus psychologist appointments with a third-party company. 
Nowadays, this service is still encouraged by X to all its employees.   
6. Conclusion 
As the research question of this paper was to demonstrate how Lean Service can develop and enhance a team learning 
process, two years of investigation using a mixed method approach, combining qualitative and quantitative data 
through service case study research, thoroughly proved its effectiveness.  
 
Two P-D-C-A Lean Service improvement cycles were performed and based on the insights gathered from the first 
cycle, an innovative and flexible training program was set up, focused on each employee and his personal context.

Hence, 27 training sessions were delivered by 16 internal trainers, in a total of 114 training hours. The total of 
participants in all these sessions was 170, with an average of 21 participants per session. Based on the quantitative 
data gathered, a high level of participation was proven, with an average of 89% obtained in the session‚Äôs evaluations, 
which demonstrates the success of these action learning activities. From the 73 enrolled employees, the average of 
participation was more than 2 sessions per worker with a dropout rate of 3.5%. The qualitative data obtained in each 
online session, supported by semi-structured interviews conducted at the end of the sessions, allowed to perceive that 
the employees wanted to learn and improve and were happy to be engaged in the learning process.  
 
The on-job-training strategy and the creation of communities of practices for the main knowledge subjects, was a bust 
to empower knowledge, and over one year, an investment of 80 on-job training hours were delivered by subject matter 
experts to workers. This action learning activity allowed to increase the number of experts within the organisation, 
particularly in problem-solving and answering critical customers‚Äô requests.    
 
Hence, after two years of investigation, it was concluded that a Lean Service approach can develop and enhance team 
learning process in this service industry organisation. In the meanwhile, further action learning activities will be 
planned to achieve continuous improvement of this team learning process.
